Leon K. Johannessen

This is me:

I have previously completed three courses in programming at NTNU: IT Grunnkurs (TDT4110), Objektorientert programmering (TDT4100), and Prototyping av interaktive media (TDT4262).

In the first course I got a basic introduction to procedural programming in Python, in the second we got a solid introduction to object oriented programming in Java. In this course we also touched the topic of functional programming. In the latter course we prototyped interactive experiences using Arduino (which is C/C++ based) and Processing (which is based on Java). In addition to this, I've built a few websites using Django/Python, Joomla!, and Craft, and I have a solid understanding of HTML/CSS. Alas my JavaScript skills are still on a novice level.

From this course I expect to obtain a solid understanding of modern web technologies, get up to speed with HTML5/CSS3, and improve my client side programming skills.

Answers to the questions:

  1. The server provides responses to the requests made by the clients over the HTTP protocol. Usually these responses are in text form, eg. a HTML document.
  2. The client requests data from the server, recieve and process it, and usually renders it to the screen of the client.
  3. An Internet Protocol (IP) address is the unique address of a node in a network. An IPv4 addresses is on the form x.x.x.x, where x can be any integer in the range 0-255.
  4. We use domain names as aliases for IP addresses. Domain Name Servers (DNS) serves as a "phone book" of domain names and their corresponding IP addresses.
  5. World Wide Web ("WWW"/"The Web") is only one of many applications that can be accessed through the Internet. Other applications that use other protocols are for instance E-mail, IRC, and SSH. The Web itself is a distributed system of hypertext documents, where one can jump between documents using hyperlinks.
  6. HyperText Markup Language (HTML) is a set of tags that, together with text, describe the content of web documents.

Created by Leon K. Johannessen (leonkj).
